title: 107_hr5437
content: The "Insurance Competitive Pricing Act of 2002" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Amendments are also included in the Act. The McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945 is amended in section 2, specifically in subsection (b), to include provisions related to monopolies, attempts to monopolize, and unlawful restraints of trade. The amendment clarifies that businesses not regulated by State law or engaged in price fixing are subject to certain restrictions. The McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945, in subsection (b), now prohibits activities such as price fixing, allocating geographical areas for insurance sales, tying insurance sales to other products or services, and monopolizing insurance business. Additionally, the amendment excludes the collection and dissemination of historical loss data from these restrictions. The McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945 prohibits activities like price fixing and monopolizing insurance business. It allows the collection and dissemination of historical loss data without restrictions on determining loss development factors or trend factors. The McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945 prohibits price fixing and monopolizing insurance business. It allows the collection of historical loss data and calculation of loss development factors without restrictions. The Insurance Competitive Pricing Act of 2002 defines terms like claims, transition period, and criteria for eligibility based on annual premiums and ownership percentages. The term 'trend factor' is defined as an adjustment for losses incurred by insurance businesses to account for changes in inflation or estimated loss costs. The Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
